quoteFirst: Here breastworks were thrown up, and skirmishing was almost continuous along the line during the forenoon, and until about 3 o’clock P. M., when the struggle was renewed on the left, and gradually extended to the center.
quoteLast: , there was a lull on the left, and the fight raged with renewed vigor on the extreme right and center, with Howard’s Eleventh and Slocum’s Twelfth corps. Late in the evening the Twenty-ninth, with the brigade, withdrew from the works, and moved back about three-fourths of a mile, where it remained during the forepart of the night, moving back and forth, and constantly skirmishing.
title:
Journal History of the Twenty-Ninth Ohio Veteran Volunteers, 1861-1865
Its Victories and its Reverses. And the campaigns and battles of Winchester, Port Republic, Cedar Mountain, Chancellorsville, Gettysburg, Lookout Mountain, Atlanta, the March to the Sea, and the campaign of the Carolinas, in which it bore an honorable part
author: SeCheverell, J. Hamp (John Hamilton)

quoteLast: inches in length and from three-fourths of an inch to one inch in width. The rind is thin and very brittle.

quoteFirst: A small pine-tree was picked up much shattered by the ice. In the afternoon of the 30th, a very dense fog came on; and,
quoteLast: , when sailing before a fresh breeze, we were suddenly involved in a heavy stream of ice. Considerable difficulty was experienced in steering through the narrow channels between the different masses in this foggy weather, and the ship received several severe blows.
title: Narrative of a Journey to the Shores of the Polar Sea, in the Years 1819-20-21-22, Volume 1
author: Franklin, John, 1786-1847

quoteFirst: The guinea-worm may be described as a nematode measuring from
quoteLast: feet in length, having a thickness of 1/10th of an inch. The body is uniformly cylindrical, terminating below in a more or less curved and mucronately pointed tail.

quoteFirst: It is a romantic river, filled with rapids and cascades, at times broadening into lakes, and again contracted into a torrent barely fifty yards wide, where the waters are precipitated over the rocks in wild splendor. For twenty-five miles above its mouth it broadens into the "Lake of the Two Mountains," from
quoteLast: miles wide. Above the city of Ottawa there are rapids terminating in the famous Chaudière Falls, where the waters plunge down forty feet, and part are said to disappear through an underground passage of unknown outlet.
title: America, Volume 4 (of 6)
author: Cook, Joel, 1842-1910
